title: Willamette Valley Multifunctional Plant List
text: Welcome to the Willamette Valley Multifunctional Plant List.

title: Ground Covers
text: Ground covers in the Pacific Northwest, particularly in the fertile and diverse Willamette Valley, play a crucial role in permaculture, landscape design, and the broader ecosystem. This region, known for its mild, wet winters and warm, dry summers, hosts a wide variety of native and adapted ground cover species that thrive in its climate, contributing to sustainable gardening, agriculture, and habitat restoration efforts.

title: Trees
text: The Willamette Valley region is home to a vast array of native and nonnative tree species that flourish in its temperate climate. They are more than just components of the landscape; they are vital, living elements that connect the soil, water, air, and wildlife. Their preservation and thoughtful integration into human landscapes are essential for the health and sustainability of the region.

title: Nuts
text: Nuts play an essential role in both agricultural and ecological contexts, particularly in regions like the Pacific Northwest, known for its diverse climates and ecosystems. This area, with its rich soils and varied weather patterns, offers an ideal environment for cultivating a wide range of nut trees, from hazelnuts, which are famously prolific in the region, to walnuts, almonds, and chestnuts. These nut-bearing trees contribute significantly to sustainable farming practices, landscape design, and wildlife support, making them a valuable asset in both rural and urban settings.

import gspread
from oauth2client.service_account import ServiceAccountCredentials
import pandas as pd
from IPython.display import display, HTML


#Setup for Google Drive and Google Sheets API
#Need to create a service account in Google Cloud to get the JSON key: https://console.cloud.google.com/iam-admin/serviceaccounts
#Need to enable Google Sheets and Google Drive APIs for the JSON key to work

scope = ["https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds",'https://www.googleapis.com/auth/spreadsheets',"https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.file","https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive"]
creds = ServiceAccountCredentials.from_json_keyfile_name('willamete-valley-plant-list-b71c56838f40.json', scope)
client = gspread.authorize(creds)

Fruit Tree Page

#Load fruit tree data from Google Sheets

sheet = client.open("Willamette Valley Multifunctional Plant List").worksheet("Trees")
data = sheet.get_all_records()
df_fruit_trees = pd.DataFrame(data)


#Set dataframe parameters

pd.set_option('display.max_columns', None)
pd.set_option('display.max_colwidth', 3)
pd.set_option('display.max_rows', None)  


# Set index for dataframe

df_fruit_trees.set_index("Botanical name", inplace=True)
df_fruit_trees.index.name = None 



df_fruit_trees.style.set_table_styles([
    {'selector': 'th', 'props': [('width', '100px')]},  # Adjust header column widths
    {'selector': 'td', 'props': [('width', '200px')]},  # Adjust data column widths
])

#Load ground cover data from Google Sheets

sheet = client.open("Willamette Valley Multifunctional Plant List").worksheet("Ground Cover")
data = sheet.get_all_records()
df_ground_cover = pd.DataFrame(data)


#Set dataframe parameters

pd.set_option('display.max_columns', None)
pd.set_option('display.max_colwidth', 3)
pd.set_option('display.max_rows', None)  


# Set index for dataframe

df_ground_cover.set_index("Botanical name", inplace=True)
df_ground_cover.index.name = None 


#images for shade tolerance
ground_cover_shade_images = {
    'Full sun':'/images/full-shade.png',
    'Partial sun':'/images/full-sun.png',
    'Full shade':'/images/full-shade.png',
    'Full sun/Partial sun':'/images/full-sun-partial-sun.png',
    'Partial sun/Full shade':'/images/partial-sun-full-shade.png'
}

#images for columns that need checks
check_image = {
    'yes':'/images/check.png',
    'no' : ' ',
    'unknown' : 'Unknown'
}

#map images to Sun/Shade column
df_ground_cover['Sun/Shade'] = df_ground_cover['Sun/Shade'].map(ground_cover_shade_images)

# Convert image paths to HTML <img> tags
df_ground_cover['Sun/Shade'] = df_ground_cover['Sun/Shade'].apply(lambda x: f'<img src="{x}" width="30" height="30" />')


# Apply the function to each column that needs to be checked
for column in ['Native', 'Medicinal', 'Nitrogen fixer', 'Insect/Bee/Birds']:
    df_ground_cover[column] = df_ground_cover[column].map(check_image)
    df_ground_cover[column] = df_ground_cover[column].apply(lambda x: f'<img src="{x}" width="30" height="30" />' if x == '/images/check.png' else x)


display(HTML(df_ground_cover.to_html(escape=False)))

Oregon Cascades mid to low altitudes. Inhabits western Cascade stream banks sometimes even growing in fast moving stream. Found in mixed forests & Ponderosa forests. Important salt substitute for some tribes. Leaves & stems are dried, burned & used as a seasoning rich in mineral salts.

title: Fruit Trees

title: Ground Covers
text:
Role in Permaculture
In permaculture, ground covers are vital for creating a self-sustaining, productive garden ecosystem. They help in several key ways:

Soil Health
Ground covers protect the soil from erosion and compaction caused by rain and wind. Their roots hold the soil in place, while their foliage intercepts water droplets, reducing their impact on the soil surface.


Moisture Retention
The dense foliage of ground covers shades the soil, significantly reducing evaporation. This is particularly beneficial in the dry summer months of the Willamette Valley, helping to maintain soil moisture without constant irrigation.


Nutrient Cycling
Many ground covers, especially nitrogen-fixing species, play a pivotal role in nutrient cycling. They can convert atmospheric nitrogen into forms accessible to other plants, enriching the soil and reducing the need for synthetic fertilizers.


Pest Management
Diverse ground cover plantings can suppress weeds and provide habitat for beneficial insects, contributing to natural pest control and reducing reliance on pesticides.

title: Ground Covers
text:
Role in Landscape Design
Ground covers are also essential in landscape design for both aesthetic and functional purposes:

Aesthetic Appeal
With a variety of textures, colors, and flowering options, ground covers can create a visually appealing understory in garden designs. They offer year-round interest and can be used to fill spaces where other plants might struggle.


Low Maintenance
Once established, many ground covers require minimal care, making them an attractive option for low-maintenance landscapes. They can reduce the need for mowing, weeding, and watering, saving time and resources.


Erosion Control
On slopes and in areas prone to erosion, ground covers can be a practical solution, stabilizing the soil and preventing runoff.


Functional Spaces
Some ground covers can withstand foot traffic, making them suitable for creating living pathways or green spaces in urban and residential designs.

title: Ground Covers
text:
Role in the Ecosystem
Beyond human-designed landscapes, ground covers play a foundational role in the Willamette Valleyâs ecosystem:

Habitat
They provide essential habitat and food sources for a variety of wildlife, including pollinators, birds, and small mammals. This supports biodiversity and promotes healthy ecosystems.


Soil Microclimate
By moderating soil temperature and moisture levels, ground covers create a favorable microclimate for soil organisms, contributing to a vibrant soil ecosystem essential for nutrient cycling and soil fertility.


Carbon Sequestration
Through photosynthesis and by adding organic matter to the soil, ground covers contribute to carbon sequestration, helping to mitigate climate change impacts.

title: Berries
text: Berries in the Pacific Northwest hold an invaluable position in cultivated gardens and wild landscapes. The area, celebrated for its rich soil, temperate climate, and adequate rainfall, is an ideal habitat for a broad spectrum of berry species.

title: Willamette Valley Multifunctional Plant List

import gspread
from oauth2client.service_account import ServiceAccountCredentials
import pandas as pd
from IPython.display import display, HTML


#Setup for Google Drive and Google Sheets API
#Need to create a service account in Google Cloud to get the JSON key: https://console.cloud.google.com/iam-admin/serviceaccounts
#Need to enable Google Sheets and Google Drive APIs for the JSON key to work

scope = ["https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds",'https://www.googleapis.com/auth/spreadsheets',"https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.file","https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive"]
creds = ServiceAccountCredentials.from_json_keyfile_name('willamete-valley-plant-list-b71c56838f40.json', scope)
client = gspread.authorize(creds)

Fruit Tree Page

#Load fruit tree data from Google Sheets

sheet = client.open("Willamette Valley Multifunctional Plant List").worksheet("Trees")
data = sheet.get_all_records()
df_fruit_trees = pd.DataFrame(data)


#Set dataframe parameters

pd.set_option('display.max_columns', None)
pd.set_option('display.max_colwidth', 3)
pd.set_option('display.max_rows', None)  


# Set index for dataframe

df_fruit_trees.set_index("Botanical name", inplace=True)
df_fruit_trees.index.name = None 



df_fruit_trees.style.set_table_styles([
    {'selector': 'th', 'props': [('width', '100px')]},  # Adjust header column widths
    {'selector': 'td', 'props': [('width', '200px')]},  # Adjust data column widths
])

#Load ground cover data from Google Sheets

sheet = client.open("Willamette Valley Multifunctional Plant List").worksheet("Ground Cover")
data = sheet.get_all_records()
df_ground_cover = pd.DataFrame(data)


#Set dataframe parameters

pd.set_option('display.max_columns', None)
pd.set_option('display.max_colwidth', 3)
pd.set_option('display.max_rows', None)  


# Set index for dataframe

df_ground_cover.set_index("Botanical name", inplace=True)
df_ground_cover.index.name = None 


#images for shade tolerance
ground_cover_shade_images = {
    'Full sun':'/images/full-shade.png',
    'Partial sun':'/images/full-sun.png',
    'Full shade':'/images/full-shade.png',
    'Full sun/Partial sun':'/images/full-sun-partial-sun.png',
    'Partial sun/Full shade':'/images/partial-sun-full-shade.png'
}

#images for columns that need checks
check_image = {
    'yes':'/images/check.png',
    'no' : '',
    'unknown' : 'unknown'
}

# Apply the function to each column that needs to be checked
for column in ['Medicinal', 'Nitrogen fixer', 'Insect/Bee/Birds']:
    df_ground_cover[column] = df_ground_cover[column].map(check_image)
    df_ground_cover[column] = df_ground_cover[column].apply(lambda x: f'<img src="{x}" width="30" height="30" />' if x.startswith('/images/') else x)


#map images to Sun/Shade column
df_ground_cover['Sun/Shade'] = df_ground_cover['Sun/Shade'].map(ground_cover_shade_images)

# Convert image paths to HTML <img> tags
df_ground_cover['Sun/Shade'] = df_ground_cover['Sun/Shade'].apply(lambda x: f'<img src="{x}" width="30" height="30" />')

import gspread
from oauth2client.service_account import ServiceAccountCredentials
import pandas as pd
from IPython.display import display, HTML


#Setup for Google Drive and Google Sheets API
#Need to create a service account in Google Cloud to get the JSON key: https://console.cloud.google.com/iam-admin/serviceaccounts
#Need to enable Google Sheets and Google Drive APIs for the JSON key to work

scope = ["https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds",'https://www.googleapis.com/auth/spreadsheets',"https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.file","https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive"]
creds = ServiceAccountCredentials.from_json_keyfile_name('willamete-valley-plant-list-b71c56838f40.json', scope)
client = gspread.authorize(creds)

Fruit Tree Page

#Load fruit tree data from Google Sheets

sheet = client.open("Willamette Valley Multifunctional Plant List").worksheet("Trees")
data = sheet.get_all_records()
df_fruit_trees = pd.DataFrame(data)


#Set dataframe parameters

pd.set_option('display.max_columns', None)
pd.set_option('display.max_colwidth', 3)
pd.set_option('display.max_rows', None)  


# Set index for dataframe

df_fruit_trees.set_index("Botanical name", inplace=True)
df_fruit_trees.index.name = None 



df_fruit_trees.style.set_table_styles([
    {'selector': 'th', 'props': [('width', '100px')]},  # Adjust header column widths
    {'selector': 'td', 'props': [('width', '200px')]},  # Adjust data column widths
])

    'yes':'/images/check.png',
    'no' : '',
    'unknown' : 'unknown'
}

# Apply the function to each column that needs to be checked
for column in ['Medicinal', 'Nitrogen fixer', 'Insect/Bee/Birds']:
    df_ground_cover[column] = df_ground_cover[column].map(check_image)

title: Berries
text:
Role in Permaculture
In permaculture, ground covers are vital for creating a self-sustaining, productive garden ecosystem. They help in several key ways:

Soil Health
Ground covers protect the soil from erosion and compaction caused by rain and wind. Their roots hold the soil in place, while their foliage intercepts water droplets, reducing their impact on the soil surface.


Moisture Retention
The dense foliage of ground covers shades the soil, significantly reducing evaporation. This is particularly beneficial in the dry summer months of the Willamette Valley, helping to maintain soil moisture without constant irrigation.


Nutrient Cycling
Many ground covers, especially nitrogen-fixing species, play a pivotal role in nutrient cycling. They can convert atmospheric nitrogen into forms accessible to other plants, enriching the soil and reducing the need for synthetic fertilizers.


Pest Management
Diverse ground cover plantings can suppress weeds and provide habitat for beneficial insects, contributing to natural pest control and reducing reliance on pesticides.

title: Berries
text:
Role in Landscape Design
In addition to their horticultural value, berries offer aesthetic and functional benefits in garden and landscape design.

Aesthetic Appeal
Berry plants, with their vibrant flowers, lush foliage, and colorful fruit, add visual interest and seasonal beauty to gardens and landscapes.


Edible Landscape
Incorporating berry plants into landscape designs offers the dual benefit of aesthetic appeal and edible produce, aligning with the principles of edible landscaping and permaculture.


Wildlife Attraction
Berry plants attract birds, bees, and other wildlife to the garden, creating lively and dynamic outdoor spaces. This not only aids in pollination but also enhances the gardenâs ecological value.


Soil Improvement
Like many perennial plants, berry bushes can help improve soil structure and fertility through their root systems and organic matter contribution.

title: Berries
text:
Role in the Ecosystem
Outside of human cultivation, wild berries play a foundational role in the Pacific Northwestâs ecosystems.

Food Web Support
Berries serve as a vital food source for a variety of wildlife, including birds, bears, and small mammals, thus playing a key role in local food webs.


Habitat Formation
Thickets of berry plants provide shelter and breeding sites for wildlife, contributing to habitat complexity and diversity.


Soil Conservation
The root systems of berry plants help stabilize the soil, preventing erosion and promoting soil health in natural landscapes.

title: Ground Covers
text:
Role in Permaculture
In permaculture, ground covers are vital for creating a self-sustaining, productive garden ecosystem. They help in several key ways:

Soil Health
Ground covers protect the soil from erosion and compaction caused by rain and wind. Their roots hold the soil in place, while their foliage intercepts water droplets, reducing their impact on the soil surface.


Moisture Retention
The dense foliage of ground covers shades the soil, significantly reducing evaporation. This is particularly beneficial in the dry summer months of the Willamette Valley, helping to maintain soil moisture without constant irrigation.


Nutrient Cycling
Many ground covers, especially nitrogen-fixing species, play a pivotal role in nutrient cycling. They can convert atmospheric nitrogen into forms accessible to other plants, enriching the soil and reducing the need for synthetic fertilizers.


Pest Management
Diverse ground cover plantings can suppress weeds and provide habitat for beneficial insects, contributing to natural pest control and reducing reliance on pesticides.

title: Ground Covers
text:
Role in Landscape Design
Ground covers are also essential in landscape design for both aesthetic and functional purposes:

Aesthetic Appeal
With a variety of textures, colors, and flowering options, ground covers can create a visually appealing understory in garden designs. They offer year-round interest and can be used to fill spaces where other plants might struggle.


Low Maintenance
Once established, many ground covers require minimal care, making them an attractive option for low-maintenance landscapes. They can reduce the need for mowing, weeding, and watering, saving time and resources.


Erosion Control
On slopes and in areas prone to erosion, ground covers can be a practical solution, stabilizing the soil and preventing runoff.


Functional Spaces
Some ground covers can withstand foot traffic, making them suitable for creating living pathways or green spaces in urban and residential designs.

title: Ground Covers
text:
Role in the Ecosystem
Beyond human-designed landscapes, ground covers play a foundational role in the Willamette Valleyâs ecosystem:

Habitat
They provide essential habitat and food sources for a variety of wildlife, including pollinators, birds, and small mammals. This supports biodiversity and promotes healthy ecosystems.


Soil Microclimate
By moderating soil temperature and moisture levels, ground covers create a favorable microclimate for soil organisms, contributing to a vibrant soil ecosystem essential for nutrient cycling and soil fertility.


Carbon Sequestration
Through photosynthesis and by adding organic matter to the soil, ground covers contribute to carbon sequestration, helping to mitigate climate change impacts.

title: Trees
text:
Role in Permaculture
In permaculture, trees are cornerstone elements that support the creation of diverse, resilient, and sustainable ecosystems. They contribute in several crucial ways:

Microclimate Creation
Trees play a significant role in creating and moderating microclimates within a garden or landscape. Their canopy provides shade, reducing soil temperature and moisture loss during the regionâs dry summers.


Soil Health
The root systems of trees help to prevent soil erosion and compaction, enhancing soil structure and fertility. Leaf litter and other organic material from trees add vital nutrients back into the soil, promoting a healthy soil microbiome.


Water Management
Trees are essential for managing water within a permaculture system. They can help to absorb excess rainfall, reducing runoff and the risk of flooding. Additionally, their presence can increase groundwater recharge.


Biodiversity Support
Trees provide habitat and food for a wide range of wildlife, including birds, insects, and mammals. This biodiversity is crucial for pollination, pest control, and creating a balanced ecosystem.

title: Trees
text:
Role in Landscape Design
Beyond their ecological benefits, trees are also pivotal in landscape design, offering structure, shade, and aesthetic appeal:

Visual Impact
With their diverse forms, foliage, flowers, and bark, trees add visual interest and define the character of a landscape. They can be used as focal points, to frame views, or to create privacy and screening.


Energy Conservation
Strategically placed trees can significantly reduce heating and cooling costs for nearby buildings by providing shade in the summer and windbreaks in the winter.


Urban Canopy Enhancement
In urban areas, trees contribute to the urban canopy, improving air quality, reducing urban heat island effects, and providing green spaces for community recreation and wellbeing.

title: Trees
text:
Role in the Ecosystem
Trees are foundational to the Willamette Valleyâs broader ecosystem, playing roles that extend far beyond human uses:

Carbon Sequestration
Trees are powerful allies in the fight against climate change, capturing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and storing carbon in their wood, leaves, and soil.


Water Cycle Regulation
Through the process of transpiration, trees play a critical role in the water cycle, helping to regulate local and regional climates.


Soil Protection
Tree roots stabilize the soil, reducing erosion and improving water infiltration, which is especially important in areas prone to heavy rainfalls.


Habitat Connectivity
Large trees and forested areas provide crucial corridors for wildlife, allowing for movement, migration, and genetic exchange between populations.

Young leaves edible as steamed or stir fry vegetable, tasty delicate flavor, also good for tea. Chinese make a tonic soup by mixing the bark with chicken or pork. Leaf tea is popular for boosting the immune system, maintaining normal blood pressure levels and strengthening legs and lower back. The bark contains the compound pinoresinal diglucoside, an agent that effectively lowers early stage high blood pressure. Bark also highly regarded to treat osteoporosis and osteoarthritis, slows and may even reverse joint degeneration, reputed to strengthen bones and ligaments (connective tissues in joints). Bark used for various other illnesses in traditional Chinese medicine. Research indicates that the leaves should be interchangeable medicinally with the bark due to their comparable chemistry. Leaves used in Chinese folk medicine as an anti-fungal to treat ringworm and ahtlete feet. Winged fruit (seed) yield 27% oil used for miscellaneous industrial purposes. Bark contains about 3% rubber b y dry weight. This solid latex, called gutta percha, is used to insulate electric cables, etc. but extraction is difficult. wood is used for furniture, fuel, etc. and tends to sucker when cut (coppice).

title: Nuts
text:
Role in Permaculture
In permaculture, nut trees serve multiple valuable functions:

Economic Value
Nut trees represent a significant agricultural commodity in the Pacific Northwest, particularly hazelnuts, which the region is renowned for globally. These crops provide a stable income for farmers due to the high demand for nuts in both local and international markets.


Soil Health
Like ground covers, nut trees play a crucial role in maintaining soil health. Their extensive root systems prevent erosion and improve soil structure, facilitating the infiltration of water and the cycling of nutrients.


Biodiversity
Diverse plantings of nut trees can enhance agricultural biodiversity, creating a more resilient and productive ecosystem. They provide habitat and food for a variety of pollinators and other beneficial wildlife, promoting ecological balance and pest control.

title: Nuts
text:
Role in Landscape Design
Nut trees also have their place in landscape design, offering both aesthetic and functional benefits:

Shade and Microclimate
Nut trees provide valuable shade, reducing local temperatures and creating comfortable outdoor living spaces. This shade can also contribute to energy savings by cooling buildings and reducing the need for air conditioning in the warmer months.


Food Production
Incorporating nut trees into residential landscapes or community gardens can provide a sustainable source of food, enhancing food security and encouraging local food systems.

title: Nuts
text:
Role in the Ecosystem
Beyond human-centric benefits, nut trees are integral to the broader ecosystem:

Wildlife Support
Nut trees offer critical resources for wildlife, including food and nesting sites. Nuts are an important food source for birds, small mammals, and some insects, contributing to ecosystem health and biodiversity.


Carbon Sequestration
By capturing and storing carbon dioxide through photosynthesis, nut trees play a part in mitigating climate change. Their contribution to carbon sequestration is especially significant given their long lifespans and substantial biomass.


Water Cycle Regulation
The extensive root systems of nut trees help regulate the water cycle, enhancing groundwater recharge and reducing surface runoff. This contributes to the sustainability of local water resources and the health of aquatic ecosystems.

import gspread
from oauth2client.service_account import ServiceAccountCredentials
import pandas as pd
from IPython.display import display, HTML


#Setup for Google Drive and Google Sheets API
#Need to create a service account in Google Cloud to get the JSON key: https://console.cloud.google.com/iam-admin/serviceaccounts
#Need to enable Google Sheets and Google Drive APIs for the JSON key to work

scope = ["https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds",'https://www.googleapis.com/auth/spreadsheets',"https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.file","https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive"]
creds = ServiceAccountCredentials.from_json_keyfile_name('willamete-valley-plant-list-b71c56838f40.json', scope)
client = gspread.authorize(creds)


#Load data from Google Sheets

sheet = client.open("Willamette Valley Multifunctional Plant List").worksheet("Ground Cover")
data = sheet.get_all_records()
df = pd.DataFrame(data)


#Set dataframe parameters

pd.set_option('display.max_columns', None)
pd.set_option('display.max_colwidth', 3)
pd.set_option('display.max_rows', None)  


# Set index for dataframe

df.set_index("Botanical name", inplace=True)
df.index.name = None 


#images for shade tolerance
ground_cover_shade_images = {
    'Full sun':'/images/full-shade.png',
    'Partial sun':'/images/full-sun.png',
    'Full shade':'/images/full-shade.png',
    'Full sun/Partial sun':'/images/full-sun-partial-sun.png',
    'Partial sun/Full shade':'/images/partial-sun-full-shade.png'
}

#images for columns that need checks
check_image = {
    'yes':'/images/check.png',
    'no' : ' ',
    'unknown' : 'Unknown'
}

#map images to Sun/Shade column
df['Sun/Shade'] = df['Sun/Shade'].map(ground_cover_shade_images)

# Convert image paths to HTML <img> tags
df['Sun/Shade'] = df['Sun/Shade'].apply(lambda x: f'<img src="{x}" width="30" height="30" />')


# Apply the function to each column that needs to be checked
for column in ['Native', 'Medicinal', 'Nitrogen fixer', 'Insect/Bee/Birds']:
    df[column] = df[column].map(check_image)
    df[column] = df[column].apply(lambda x: f'<img src="{x}" width="30" height="30" />' if x == '/images/check.png' else x)


display(HTML(df.to_html(escape=False)))

Young leaves edible as steamed or stir fry vegetable, tasty delicate flavor, also good for tea. Chinese make a tonic soup by mixing the bark with chicken or pork. Leaf tea is popular for boosting the immune system, maintaining normal blood pressure levels and strengthening legs and lower back. The bark contains the compound pinoresinal diglucoside, an agent that effectively lowers early stage high blood pressure. Bark also highly regarded to treat osteoporosis and osteoarthritis, slows and may even reverse joint degeneration, reputed to strengthen bones and ligaments (connective tissues in joints). Bark used for various other illnesses in traditional Chinese medicine. Research indicates that the leaves should be interchangeable medicinally with the bark due to their comparable chemistry. Leaves used in Chinese folk medicine as an anti-fungal to treat ringworm and ahtlete feet. Winged fruit (seed) yield 27% oil used for miscellaneous industrial purposes. Bark contains about 3% rubber b y dry weight. This solid latex, called gutta percha, is used to insulate electric cables, etc. but extraction is difficult. wood is used for furniture, fuel, etc. and tends to sucker when cut (coppice).

title: Willamette Valley Multifunctional Plant List
text:
import gspread
from oauth2client.service_account import ServiceAccountCredentials
import pandas as pd
from IPython.display import display, HTML


#Setup for Google Drive and Google Sheets API
#Need to create a service account in Google Cloud to get the JSON key: https://console.cloud.google.com/iam-admin/serviceaccounts
#Need to enable Google Sheets and Google Drive APIs for the JSON key to work

scope = ["https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds",'https://www.googleapis.com/auth/spreadsheets',"https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.file","https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive"]
creds = ServiceAccountCredentials.from_json_keyfile_name('willamete-valley-plant-list-b71c56838f40.json', scope)
client = gspread.authorize(creds)


#Load data from Google Sheets

sheet = client.open("Willamette Valley Multifunctional Plant List").worksheet("Fruit Trees")
data = sheet.get_all_records()
df = pd.DataFrame(data)


#Set dataframe parameters

pd.set_option('display.max_columns', None)
pd.set_option('display.max_colwidth', 3)
pd.set_option('display.max_rows', None)  


# Set index for dataframe

df.set_index("Botanical name", inplace=True)
df.index.name = None 


#images for shade tolerance
ground_cover_shade_images = {
    'Full sun':'/images/full-shade.png',
    'Partial sun':'/images/full-sun.png',
    'Full shade':'/images/full-shade.png',
    'Full sun/Partial sun':'/images/full-sun-partial-sun.png',
    'Partial sun/Full shade':'/images/partial-sun-full-shade.png'
}

#images for columns that need checks
check_image = {
    'yes':'/images/check.png',
    'no' : ' ',
    'unknown' : 'Unknown'
}

#map images to Sun/Shade column
df['Sun/Shade'] = df['Sun/Shade'].map(ground_cover_shade_images)

# Convert image paths to HTML <img> tags
df['Sun/Shade'] = df['Sun/Shade'].apply(lambda x: f'<img src="{x}" width="30" height="30" />')


# Apply the function to each column that needs to be checked
for column in ['Native', 'Medicinal', 'Nitrogen fixer', 'Insect/Bee/Birds']:
    df[column] = df[column].map(check_image)
    df[column] = df[column].apply(lambda x: f'<img src="{x}" width="30" height="30" />' if x == '/images/check.png' else x)


display(HTML(df.to_html(escape=False)))

title: Ground Covers
text:
Role in Permaculture
In permaculture, ground covers are vital for creating a self-sustaining, productive garden ecosystem. They help in several key ways:

Soil Health
Ground covers protect the soil from erosion and compaction caused by rain and wind. Their roots hold the soil in place, while their foliage intercepts water droplets, reducing their impact on the soil surface.


Moisture Retention
The dense foliage of ground covers shades the soil, significantly reducing evaporation. This is particularly beneficial in the dry summer months of the Willamette Valley, helping to maintain soil moisture without constant irrigation.


Nutrient Cycling
Many ground covers, especially nitrogen-fixing species, play a pivotal role in nutrient cycling. They can convert atmospheric nitrogen into forms accessible to other plants, enriching the soil and reducing the need for synthetic fertilizers.


Pest Management
Diverse ground cover plantings can suppress weeds and provide habitat for beneficial insects, contributing to natural pest control and reducing reliance on pesticides.

title: Ground Covers
text:
Role in Landscape Design
Ground covers are also essential in landscape design for both aesthetic and functional purposes:

Aesthetic Appeal
With a variety of textures, colors, and flowering options, ground covers can create a visually appealing understory in garden designs. They offer year-round interest and can be used to fill spaces where other plants might struggle.


Low Maintenance
Once established, many ground covers require minimal care, making them an attractive option for low-maintenance landscapes. They can reduce the need for mowing, weeding, and watering, saving time and resources.


Erosion Control
On slopes and in areas prone to erosion, ground covers can be a practical solution, stabilizing the soil and preventing runoff.


Functional Spaces
Some ground covers can withstand foot traffic, making them suitable for creating living pathways or green spaces in urban and residential designs.

title: Ground Covers
text:
Role in the Ecosystem
Beyond human-designed landscapes, ground covers play a foundational role in the Willamette Valleyâs ecosystem:

Habitat
They provide essential habitat and food sources for a variety of wildlife, including pollinators, birds, and small mammals. This supports biodiversity and promotes healthy ecosystems.


Soil Microclimate
By moderating soil temperature and moisture levels, ground covers create a favorable microclimate for soil organisms, contributing to a vibrant soil ecosystem essential for nutrient cycling and soil fertility.


Carbon Sequestration
Through photosynthesis and by adding organic matter to the soil, ground covers contribute to carbon sequestration, helping to mitigate climate change impacts.

import gspread
from oauth2client.service_account import ServiceAccountCredentials
import pandas as pd
from IPython.display import display, HTML


#Setup for Google Drive and Google Sheets API
#Need to create a service account in Google Cloud to get the JSON key: https://console.cloud.google.com/iam-admin/serviceaccounts
#Need to enable Google Sheets and Google Drive APIs for the JSON key to work

scope = ["https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds",'https://www.googleapis.com/auth/spreadsheets',"https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.file","https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive"]
creds = ServiceAccountCredentials.from_json_keyfile_name('willamete-valley-plant-list-b71c56838f40.json', scope)
client = gspread.authorize(creds)

Fruit Tree Page

#Load fruit tree data from Google Sheets

sheet = client.open("Willamette Valley Multifunctional Plant List").worksheet("Trees")
data = sheet.get_all_records()
df_fruit_trees = pd.DataFrame(data)


#Set dataframe parameters

pd.set_option('display.max_columns', None)
pd.set_option('display.max_colwidth', 3)
pd.set_option('display.max_rows', None)  


# Set index for dataframe

df_fruit_trees.set_index("Botanical name", inplace=True)
df_fruit_trees.index.name = None 



df_fruit_trees.style.set_table_styles([
    {'selector': 'th', 'props': [('width', '100px')]},  # Adjust header column widths
    {'selector': 'td', 'props': [('width', '200px')]},  # Adjust data column widths
])

title: Fruit Trees
text:
Role in Permaculture
In the sphere of permaculture, fruit trees are celebrated for their ability to forge synergies that enhance garden and ecosystem productivity.

Polyculture and Biodiversity
Fruit trees are keystones in polyculture systems, where their integration with other plants leads to heightened biodiversity. This diversity bolsters ecosystem resilience, mitigating pests and diseases naturally.


Microclimate Creation
The canopy of fruit trees provides shade, moderates temperature, and shelters underplantings, creating a hospitable microclimate for a myriad of plant species and promoting soil moisture retention.


Vertical Layering
Fruit trees add a crucial vertical dimension to permaculture designs, allowing for more efficient use of space. This layering technique enables the coexistence of multiple plant species in a single area, optimizing light exposure and nutrient availability.


Soil Health
The deep root systems of fruit trees help in aerating the soil and cycling nutrients, contributing to the overall health and fertility of the soil. Leaf litter and dropped fruit add organic matter, enhancing soil structure and nutrient content.


Nutritional Contributions
The fruits borne by these trees are rich in vitamins, minerals, and fibers, offering essential nutritional benefits to human diets and supporting food security.


Heritage and Cultural Significance
Many fruit tree varieties have historical and cultural significance, reflecting the agricultural heritage of the region. Preserving heirloom varieties contributes to cultural identity and biodiversity.

title: Fruit Trees
text:
Role in Landscape Design
Fruit trees also play a crucial role in landscape design, combining aesthetics with functionality.

Shade and Structure
The substantial size and canopy of fruit trees provide shade, cooling effects, and structural elements to garden designs, creating comfortable and inviting outdoor spaces.


Edible Landscaping
Incorporating fruit trees into landscape designs not only beautifies the space but also yields edible rewards, embodying the principles of edible landscaping and sustainability.

title: Fruit Trees
text:
Role in the Ecosystem
Fruit trees contribute significantly to the ecological balance of the Willamette Valley and beyond.

Wildlife Habitat
Fruit trees offer habitat and food sources for a variety of wildlife, including birds, bees, and other pollinators, enhancing local biodiversity and ecosystem health.


Carbon Sequestration
By capturing carbon dioxide, fruit trees play a part in mitigating climate change, contributing to the sequestration of carbon and the reduction of greenhouse gas levels in the atmosphere.


Water Cycle Regulation
Through transpiration and the interception of rainfall, fruit trees play a role in the regulation of the local water cycle, contributing to groundwater recharge and reducing runoff.

import gspread
from oauth2client.service_account import ServiceAccountCredentials
import pandas as pd
from IPython.display import display, HTML


#Setup for Google Drive and Google Sheets API
#Need to create a service account in Google Cloud to get the JSON key: https://console.cloud.google.com/iam-admin/serviceaccounts
#Need to enable Google Sheets and Google Drive APIs for the JSON key to work

scope = ["https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds",'https://www.googleapis.com/auth/spreadsheets',"https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.file","https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive"]
creds = ServiceAccountCredentials.from_json_keyfile_name('willamete-valley-plant-list-b71c56838f40.json', scope)
client = gspread.authorize(creds)


#Load data from Google Sheets

sheet = client.open("Willamette Valley Multifunctional Plant List").worksheet("Ground Cover")
data = sheet.get_all_records()
df = pd.DataFrame(data)


#Set dataframe parameters

pd.set_option('display.max_columns', None)
pd.set_option('display.max_colwidth', 3)
pd.set_option('display.max_rows', None)  


# Set index for dataframe

df.set_index("Botanical name", inplace=True)
df.index.name = None 


#images for shade tolerance
ground_cover_shade_images = {
    'Full sun':'/images/full-shade.png',
    'Partial sun':'/images/full-sun.png',
    'Full shade':'/images/full-shade.png',
    'Full sun/Partial sun':'/images/full-sun-partial-sun.png',
    'Partial sun/Full shade':'/images/partial-sun-full-shade.png'
}

#images for columns that need checks
check_image = {
    'yes':'/images/check.png',
    'no' : ' ',
    'unknown' : 'Unknown'
}

#map images to Sun/Shade column
df['Sun/Shade'] = df['Sun/Shade'].map(ground_cover_shade_images)

# Convert image paths to HTML <img> tags
df['Sun/Shade'] = df['Sun/Shade'].apply(lambda x: f'<img src="{x}" width="30" height="30" />')


# Apply the function to each column that needs to be checked
for column in ['Native', 'Medicinal', 'Nitrogen fixer', 'Insect/Bee/Birds']:
    df[column] = df[column].map(check_image)
    df[column] = df[column].apply(lambda x: f'<img src="{x}" width="30" height="30" />' if x == '/images/check.png' else x)


display(HTML(df.to_html(escape=False)))

Important salt substitute for some tribes. Leaves & stems are dried, burned & used as a seasoning rich in mineral salts.

title: Willamette Valley Multifunctional Plant List
text:
import gspread
from oauth2client.service_account import ServiceAccountCredentials
import pandas as pd
from IPython.display import display, HTML


#Setup for Google Drive and Google Sheets API
#Need to create a service account in Google Cloud to get the JSON key: https://console.cloud.google.com/iam-admin/serviceaccounts
#Need to enable Google Sheets and Google Drive APIs for the JSON key to work

scope = ["https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds",'https://www.googleapis.com/auth/spreadsheets',"https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.file","https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive"]
creds = ServiceAccountCredentials.from_json_keyfile_name('willamete-valley-plant-list-b71c56838f40.json', scope)
client = gspread.authorize(creds)


#Load data from Google Sheets

sheet = client.open("Willamette Valley Multifunctional Plant List").worksheet("Vines")
data = sheet.get_all_records()
df = pd.DataFrame(data)


#Set dataframe parameters

pd.set_option('display.max_columns', None)
pd.set_option('display.max_colwidth', 3)
pd.set_option('display.max_rows', None)  


# Set index for dataframe

df.set_index("Botanical name", inplace=True)
df.index.name = None 


#images for shade tolerance
ground_cover_shade_images = {
    'Full sun':'/images/full-shade.png',
    'Partial sun':'/images/full-sun.png',
    'Full shade':'/images/full-shade.png',
    'Full sun/Partial sun':'/images/full-sun-partial-sun.png',
    'Partial sun/Full shade':'/images/partial-sun-full-shade.png'
}

#images for columns that need checks
check_image = {
    'yes':'/images/check.png',
    'no' : ' ',
    'unknown' : 'Unknown'
}

#map images to Sun/Shade column
df['Sun/Shade'] = df['Sun/Shade'].map(ground_cover_shade_images)

# Convert image paths to HTML <img> tags
df['Sun/Shade'] = df['Sun/Shade'].apply(lambda x: f'<img src="{x}" width="30" height="30" />')


# Apply the function to each column that needs to be checked
for column in ['Native', 'Medicinal', 'Nitrogen fixer', 'Insect/Bee/Birds']:
    df[column] = df[column].map(check_image)
    df[column] = df[column].apply(lambda x: f'<img src="{x}" width="30" height="30" />' if x == '/images/check.png' else x)


display(HTML(df.to_html(escape=False)))

title: Ground Covers
text:
Role in Permaculture
In permaculture, ground covers are vital for creating a self-sustaining, productive garden ecosystem. They help in several key ways:

Soil Health
Ground covers protect the soil from erosion and compaction caused by rain and wind. Their roots hold the soil in place, while their foliage intercepts water droplets, reducing their impact on the soil surface.


Moisture Retention
The dense foliage of ground covers shades the soil, significantly reducing evaporation. This is particularly beneficial in the dry summer months of the Willamette Valley, helping to maintain soil moisture without constant irrigation.


Nutrient Cycling
Many ground covers, especially nitrogen-fixing species, play a pivotal role in nutrient cycling. They can convert atmospheric nitrogen into forms accessible to other plants, enriching the soil and reducing the need for synthetic fertilizers.


Pest Management
Diverse ground cover plantings can suppress weeds and provide habitat for beneficial insects, contributing to natural pest control and reducing reliance on pesticides.

title: Ground Covers
text:
Role in Landscape Design
Ground covers are also essential in landscape design for both aesthetic and functional purposes:

Aesthetic Appeal
With a variety of textures, colors, and flowering options, ground covers can create a visually appealing understory in garden designs. They offer year-round interest and can be used to fill spaces where other plants might struggle.


Low Maintenance
Once established, many ground covers require minimal care, making them an attractive option for low-maintenance landscapes. They can reduce the need for mowing, weeding, and watering, saving time and resources.


Erosion Control
On slopes and in areas prone to erosion, ground covers can be a practical solution, stabilizing the soil and preventing runoff.


Functional Spaces
Some ground covers can withstand foot traffic, making them suitable for creating living pathways or green spaces in urban and residential designs.

title: Ground Covers
text:
Role in the Ecosystem
Beyond human-designed landscapes, ground covers play a foundational role in the Willamette Valleyâs ecosystem:

Habitat
They provide essential habitat and food sources for a variety of wildlife, including pollinators, birds, and small mammals. This supports biodiversity and promotes healthy ecosystems.


Soil Microclimate
By moderating soil temperature and moisture levels, ground covers create a favorable microclimate for soil organisms, contributing to a vibrant soil ecosystem essential for nutrient cycling and soil fertility.


Carbon Sequestration
Through photosynthesis and by adding organic matter to the soil, ground covers contribute to carbon sequestration, helping to mitigate climate change impacts.

title: Shrubs
text:
Role in Permaculture
In permaculture designs, shrubs are key elements that enhance ecosystem diversity, resilience, and sustainability. They contribute in numerous vital ways:

Microclimate Regulation
Shrubs help to create and modulate microclimates within gardens and landscapes. Their varied heights and densities offer shade and wind protection, moderating soil and air temperatures around them.


Soil Health Improvement
Shrubs contribute to soil health by preventing erosion and improving soil structure through their extensive root systems. The decomposition of leaf litter and woody material from shrubs adds organic matter to the soil, enriching it with nutrients.


Biodiversity Enhancement
Shrubs provide crucial habitats and food sources for a wide array of wildlife, including birds, insects, and small mammals. This supports pollination, pest control, and contributes to a balanced and dynamic ecosystem.

title: Shrubs
text:
Role in Landscape Design
Shrubs offer structural diversity, aesthetic beauty, and functional benefits in landscape design:

Visual and Sensory Appeal
Shrubs bring a variety of forms, colors, textures, and fragrances to gardens and landscapes. They can serve as attractive focal points, hedges, borders, and background plantings, offering year-round visual interest.


Energy Efficiency
Properly placed shrubs can reduce energy costs by providing cooling shade in the summer and acting as windbreaks in the winter, thereby reducing the heating and cooling needs of adjacent buildings.


Privacy and Screening
Shrubs are effective for creating privacy screens and reducing noise pollution, making them invaluable in both residential and urban settings.


Wildlife Gardens
Incorporating native shrubs into landscape designs can create vibrant wildlife gardens, attracting pollinators and birds, and providing shelter and food for various species.

title: Shrubs
text:
Role in the Ecosystem
Beyond their value to humans, shrubs play foundational roles in the broader ecosystem of the Willamette Valley:

Soil Conservation
The root systems of shrubs stabilize the soil, preventing erosion, particularly in vulnerable areas such as slopes and riparian zones.


Ecological Connectivity
Shrubs form essential layers in forested areas and open landscapes, providing connectivity and transition habitats that support wildlife movement and biodiversity.

title: Vines
text:
Role in Permaculture
In permaculture design, vines serve several critical functions that enhance the productivity and sustainability of gardens and ecosystems.

Vertical Growth
Vines utilize vertical space, offering solutions for small gardens or areas where ground space is limited. They can be trained to grow up trellises, fences, and walls, maximizing the productive use of space.


Living Structures
Vines can be used to create living structures such as green tunnels, arbors, and pergolas, adding beauty and functionality to garden designs. These structures can provide habitat and support for other species as well.


Companion Planting
Many vine species can act as beneficial companions to other plants. For example, grapevines can provide shade and moisture retention for understory crops, while some climbing beans can fix nitrogen in the soil, benefiting neighboring plants.


Role in Landscape Design
Vines are also crucial in landscape design, offering aesthetic and practical benefits.


Microclimate Creation
Vines can alter microclimates by providing shade and cooling areas during the hot summer months. This can be especially beneficial for creating comfortable outdoor living spaces or for protecting more sensitive plants from intense sun exposure.


Privacy and Screening
Vines can be used to create natural screens, providing privacy and reducing noise in urban and residential areas. They can quickly cover fences and walls, creating green barriers that enhance the sense of seclusion.

title: Vines
text:
Role in Landscape Design
Ground covers are also essential in landscape design for both aesthetic and functional purposes:

Aesthetic Appeal
With a variety of textures, colors, and flowering options, ground covers can create a visually appealing understory in garden designs. They offer year-round interest and can be used to fill spaces where other plants might struggle.


Low Maintenance
Once established, many ground covers require minimal care, making them an attractive option for low-maintenance landscapes. They can reduce the need for mowing, weeding, and watering, saving time and resources.


Erosion Control
On slopes and in areas prone to erosion, ground covers can be a practical solution, stabilizing the soil and preventing runoff.


Functional Spaces
Some ground covers can withstand foot traffic, making them suitable for creating living pathways or green spaces in urban and residential designs.

title: Vines
text:
Role in the Ecosystem
Beyond their use in human-centered landscapes, vines play a foundational role in the Pacific Northwestâs ecosystems.

Habitat and Food
Vines provide essential habitat and food sources for a wide range of wildlife. Many species produce fruits that are vital food sources for birds, mammals, and insects.


Connectivity
In natural landscapes, vines can act as connectors, linking different parts of the ecosystem together. This can facilitate the movement of species across the landscape, promoting genetic diversity and resilience.


Erosion Control
Certain types of vines are effective at stabilizing soil and preventing erosion, especially on slopes or areas prone to soil degradation. Their root systems help to hold the soil in place, while their foliage reduces the impact of raindrops.


Biodiversity
Incorporating a variety of vines into landscapes can support biodiversity by offering a range of habitats, nesting sites, and food sources for birds, insects, and other wildlife.

import gspread
from oauth2client.service_account import ServiceAccountCredentials
import pandas as pd
from IPython.display import display, HTML


#Setup for Google Drive and Google Sheets API
#Need to create a service account in Google Cloud to get the JSON key: https://console.cloud.google.com/iam-admin/serviceaccounts
#Need to enable Google Sheets and Google Drive APIs for the JSON key to work

scope = ["https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds",'https://www.googleapis.com/auth/spreadsheets',"https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.file","https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive"]
creds = ServiceAccountCredentials.from_json_keyfile_name('willamete-valley-plant-list-b71c56838f40.json', scope)
client = gspread.authorize(creds)

Fruit Tree Page

#Load fruit tree data from Google Sheets

sheet = client.open("Willamette Valley Multifunctional Plant List").worksheet("Trees")
data = sheet.get_all_records()
df_fruit_trees = pd.DataFrame(data)


#Set dataframe parameters

pd.set_option('display.max_columns', None)
pd.set_option('display.max_colwidth', 3)
pd.set_option('display.max_rows', None)  


# Set index for dataframe

df_fruit_trees.set_index("Botanical name", inplace=True)
df_fruit_trees.index.name = None 



df_fruit_trees.style.set_table_styles([
    {'selector': 'th', 'props': [('width', '100px')]},  # Adjust header column widths

])

title: Berries
text:
Role in Horticulture
Berries are a cornerstone of horticultural practices in the Pacific Northwest, offering a range of benefits from the home garden to commercial agriculture.

Nutritional Value
Berries are highly prized for their nutritional content, being rich in vitamins, antioxidants, and fiber. They provide essential health benefits and are a delicious component of the local diet.


Economic Value
The cultivation of berries, including strawberries, blueberries, and raspberries, represents a significant agricultural activity in the region. It supports local economies through both domestic consumption and export.


Pollination Support
Berry plants are crucial in supporting pollinators. Their flowers offer nectar and pollen to a wide array of insects, thereby contributing to the health and sustainability of pollination networks.


Biodiversity
Diverse berry plantings can enhance genetic diversity in agricultural landscapes, reducing vulnerability to pests and diseases and promoting ecological resilience.

import gspread
from oauth2client.service_account import ServiceAccountCredentials
import pandas as pd
from IPython.display import display, HTML


#Setup for Google Drive and Google Sheets API
#Need to create a service account in Google Cloud to get the JSON key: https://console.cloud.google.com/iam-admin/serviceaccounts
#Need to enable Google Sheets and Google Drive APIs for the JSON key to work

scope = ["https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds",'https://www.googleapis.com/auth/spreadsheets',"https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.file","https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive"]
creds = ServiceAccountCredentials.from_json_keyfile_name('willamete-valley-plant-list-b71c56838f40.json', scope)
client = gspread.authorize(creds)

Fruit Tree Page

#Load fruit tree data from Google Sheets

sheet = client.open("Willamette Valley Multifunctional Plant List").worksheet("Trees")
data = sheet.get_all_records()
df_fruit_trees = pd.DataFrame(data)


#Set dataframe parameters

pd.set_option('display.max_columns', None)
pd.set_option('display.max_colwidth', 3)
pd.set_option('display.max_rows', None)  


# Set index for dataframe

df_fruit_trees.set_index("Botanical name", inplace=True)
df_fruit_trees.index.name = None 



df_fruit_trees.style.set_table_styles([
    {'selector': 'th', 'props': [('width', '100px')]},  # Adjust header column widths
    {'selector': 'td', 'props': [('width', '200px')]},  # Adjust data column widths
])

import gspread
from oauth2client.service_account import ServiceAccountCredentials
import pandas as pd
from IPython.display import display, HTML


#Setup for Google Drive and Google Sheets API
#Need to create a service account in Google Cloud to get the JSON key: https://console.cloud.google.com/iam-admin/serviceaccounts
#Need to enable Google Sheets and Google Drive APIs for the JSON key to work

scope = ["https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds",'https://www.googleapis.com/auth/spreadsheets',"https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.file","https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive"]
creds = ServiceAccountCredentials.from_json_keyfile_name('willamete-valley-plant-list-b71c56838f40.json', scope)
client = gspread.authorize(creds)

Fruit Tree Page

#Load fruit tree data from Google Sheets

sheet = client.open("Willamette Valley Multifunctional Plant List").worksheet("Trees")
data = sheet.get_all_records()
df_fruit_trees = pd.DataFrame(data)


#Set dataframe parameters

pd.set_option('display.max_columns', None)
pd.set_option('display.max_colwidth', 3)
pd.set_option('display.max_rows', None)  


# Set index for dataframe

df_fruit_trees.set_index("Botanical name", inplace=True)
df_fruit_trees.index.name = None 



df_fruit_trees.style.set_table_styles([
    {'selector': 'th', 'props': [('width', '100px')]},  # Adjust header column widths
    {'selector': 'td', 'props': [('width', '200px')]},  # Adjust data column widths
])

Young leaves & possibly flower stalks contain a modest amount of Purrolizidine Alkaloids that cause permanent liver damage. Mature leaves said to have almost none. Roots (rhizomes) may have none of this alkaloid. Indian Tribes (some) ate young leaves & flower heads. Also, peeled young stalks cooked / rhizomes sometimes eaten if not used for medicine. Important salt substitute for some tribes. Leaves & stems are dried, burned & used as a seasoning rich in mineral salts.

title: Willamette Valley Multifunctional Plant List

import gspread
from oauth2client.service_account import ServiceAccountCredentials
import pandas as pd
from IPython.display import display, HTML


#Setup for Google Drive and Google Sheets API
#Need to create a service account in Google Cloud to get the JSON key: https://console.cloud.google.com/iam-admin/serviceaccounts
#Need to enable Google Sheets and Google Drive APIs for the JSON key to work

scope = ["https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds",'https://www.googleapis.com/auth/spreadsheets',"https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.file","https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive"]
creds = ServiceAccountCredentials.from_json_keyfile_name('willamete-valley-plant-list-b71c56838f40.json', scope)
client = gspread.authorize(creds)

Fruit Tree Page

#Load fruit tree data from Google Sheets

sheet = client.open("Willamette Valley Multifunctional Plant List").worksheet("Trees")
data = sheet.get_all_records()
df_fruit_trees = pd.DataFrame(data)


#Set dataframe parameters

pd.set_option('display.max_columns', None)
pd.set_option('display.max_colwidth', 3)
pd.set_option('display.max_rows', None)  


# Set index for dataframe

df_fruit_trees.set_index("Botanical name", inplace=True)
df_fruit_trees.index.name = None 



df_fruit_trees.style.set_table_styles([
    {'selector': 'th', 'props': [('width', '100px')]},  # Adjust header column widths
    {'selector': 'td', 'props': [('width', '200px')]},  # Adjust data column widths
])

Oregon Cascades mid to low altitudes. Inhabits western Cascade stream banks sometimes even growing in fast moving stream. Found in mixed forests & Ponderosa forests. Young leaves & possibly flower stalks contain a modest amount of Purrolizidine Alkaloids that cause permanent liver damage. Mature leaves said to have almost none. Roots (rhizomes) may have none of this alkaloid. Indian Tribes (some) ate young leaves & flower heads. Also, peeled young stalks cooked / rhizomes sometimes eaten if not used for medicine. Important salt substitute for some tribes. Leaves & stems are dried, burned & used as a seasoning rich in mineral salts.

import gspread
from oauth2client.service_account import ServiceAccountCredentials
import pandas as pd
from IPython.display import display, HTML


#Setup for Google Drive and Google Sheets API
#Need to create a service account in Google Cloud to get the JSON key: https://console.cloud.google.com/iam-admin/serviceaccounts
#Need to enable Google Sheets and Google Drive APIs for the JSON key to work

scope = ["https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds",'https://www.googleapis.com/auth/spreadsheets',"https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.file","https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive"]
creds = ServiceAccountCredentials.from_json_keyfile_name('willamete-valley-plant-list-b71c56838f40.json', scope)
client = gspread.authorize(creds)

Fruit Tree Page

#Load fruit tree data from Google Sheets

sheet = client.open("Willamette Valley Multifunctional Plant List").worksheet("Trees")
data = sheet.get_all_records()
df_fruit_trees = pd.DataFrame(data)


#Set dataframe parameters

pd.set_option('display.max_columns', None)
pd.set_option('display.max_colwidth', 3)
pd.set_option('display.max_rows', None)  


# Set index for dataframe

df_fruit_trees.set_index("Botanical name", inplace=True)
df_fruit_trees.index.name = None 



df_fruit_trees.style.set_table_styles([
    {'selector': 'th', 'props': [('width', '100px')]},  # Adjust header column widths
    {'selector': 'td', 'props': [('width', '200px')]},  # Adjust data column widths
])

Very young leaf stalks & flower stalks peeled & eaten fresh. Loses flavor cooked. Steam older stalks (bland & stringy) / reported from Benton County south. More common S. Oregon Cascades mid to low altitudes. Inhabits western Cascade stream banks sometimes even growing in fast moving stream. Found in mixed forests & Ponderosa forests. Young leaves & possibly flower stalks contain a modest amount of Purrolizidine Alkaloids that cause permanent liver damage. Mature leaves said to have almost none. Roots (rhizomes) may have none of this alkaloid. Indian Tribes (some) ate young leaves & flower heads. Also, peeled young stalks cooked / rhizomes sometimes eaten if not used for medicine. Important salt substitute for some tribes. Leaves & stems are dried, burned & used as a seasoning rich in mineral salts.

import gspread
from oauth2client.service_account import ServiceAccountCredentials
import pandas as pd
from IPython.display import display, HTML


#Setup for Google Drive and Google Sheets API
#Need to create a service account in Google Cloud to get the JSON key: https://console.cloud.google.com/iam-admin/serviceaccounts
#Need to enable Google Sheets and Google Drive APIs for the JSON key to work

scope = ["https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds",'https://www.googleapis.com/auth/spreadsheets',"https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.file","https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive"]
creds = ServiceAccountCredentials.from_json_keyfile_name('willamete-valley-plant-list-b71c56838f40.json', scope)
client = gspread.authorize(creds)

Fruit Tree Page

#Load fruit tree data from Google Sheets

sheet = client.open("Willamette Valley Multifunctional Plant List").worksheet("Trees")
data = sheet.get_all_records()
df_fruit_trees = pd.DataFrame(data)


#Set dataframe parameters

pd.set_option('display.max_columns', None)
pd.set_option('display.max_colwidth', 3)
pd.set_option('display.max_rows', None)  


# Set index for dataframe

df_fruit_trees.set_index("Botanical name", inplace=True)
df_fruit_trees.index.name = None 



df_fruit_trees.style.set_table_styles([
    {'selector': 'th', 'props': [('width', '100px')]},  # Adjust header column widths
    {'selector': 'td', 'props': [('width', '200px')]},  # Adjust data column widths
])

import gspread
from oauth2client.service_account import ServiceAccountCredentials
import pandas as pd
from IPython.display import display, HTML


#Setup for Google Drive and Google Sheets API
#Need to create a service account in Google Cloud to get the JSON key: https://console.cloud.google.com/iam-admin/serviceaccounts
#Need to enable Google Sheets and Google Drive APIs for the JSON key to work

scope = ["https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds",'https://www.googleapis.com/auth/spreadsheets',"https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.file","https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive"]
creds = ServiceAccountCredentials.from_json_keyfile_name('willamete-valley-plant-list-b71c56838f40.json', scope)
client = gspread.authorize(creds)

Fruit Tree Page

#Load fruit tree data from Google Sheets

sheet = client.open("Willamette Valley Multifunctional Plant List").worksheet("Trees")
data = sheet.get_all_records()
df_fruit_trees = pd.DataFrame(data)


#Set dataframe parameters

pd.set_option('display.max_columns', None)
pd.set_option('display.max_colwidth', 3)
pd.set_option('display.max_rows', None)  


# Set index for dataframe

df_fruit_trees.set_index("Botanical name", inplace=True)
df_fruit_trees.index.name = None 



df_fruit_trees.style.set_table_styles([
    {'selector': 'th', 'props': [('width', '100px')]},  # Adjust header column widths
    {'selector': 'td', 'props': [('width', '200px')]},  # Adjust data column widths
])

}

check_image = {
    'yes':'/images/check.png',
    'no' : '',
    'unknown' : 'unknown'
}

# Apply the function to each column that needs to be checked
for column in ['Medicinal', 'Nitrogen fixer', 'Insect/Bee/Birds']:
    df_ground_cover[column] = df_ground_cover[column].map(check_image)
    df_ground_cover[column] = df_ground_cover[column].apply(lambda x: f'<img src="{x}" width="30" height="30" />' if x.startswith('/images/') else x)


#map images to Sun/Shade column

Young leaves & possibly flower stalks contain a modest amount of Purrolizidine Alkaloids that cause permanent liver damage. Mature leaves said to have almost none. Roots (rhizomes) may have none of this alkaloid. Indian Tribes (some) ate young leaves & flower heads. Also, peeled young stalks cooked / rhizomes sometimes eaten if not used for medicine. Important salt substitute for some tribes. Leaves & stems are dried, burned & used as a seasoning rich in mineral salts.

import gspread
from oauth2client.service_account import ServiceAccountCredentials
import pandas as pd
from IPython.display import display, HTML


#Setup for Google Drive and Google Sheets API
#Need to create a service account in Google Cloud to get the JSON key: https://console.cloud.google.com/iam-admin/serviceaccounts
#Need to enable Google Sheets and Google Drive APIs for the JSON key to work

scope = ["https://spreadsheets.google.com/feeds",'https://www.googleapis.com/auth/spreadsheets',"https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.file","https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive"]
creds = ServiceAccountCredentials.from_json_keyfile_name('willamete-valley-plant-list-b71c56838f40.json', scope)
client = gspread.authorize(creds)

Fruit Tree Page

#Load fruit tree data from Google Sheets

sheet = client.open("Willamette Valley Multifunctional Plant List").worksheet("Trees")
data = sheet.get_all_records()
df_fruit_trees = pd.DataFrame(data)


#Set dataframe parameters

pd.set_option('display.max_columns', None)
pd.set_option('display.max_colwidth', 3)
pd.set_option('display.max_rows', None)  


# Set index for dataframe

df_fruit_trees.set_index("Botanical name", inplace=True)
df_fruit_trees.index.name = None 



df_fruit_trees.style.set_table_styles([
    {'selector': 'th', 'props': [('width', '100px')]},  # Adjust header column widths
    {'selector': 'td', 'props': [('width', '200px')]},  # Adjust data column widths
])
